title: Determinants of digital innovation in the public sector
analysis_techniques: Tobit regression; Descriptive statistics; Geographic Information System (GIS) analysis
research_topics: Determinants, risks and impacts; Implementation and governance
theoretical_background: Demand-pull innovation; Upper echelons theory; Isomorphic pressure; Electoral incentive hypothesis
technology_discussed: Artificial intelligence; Big data; Internet of Things (IoT); Augmented reality (AR); Blockchain
research_description: This study investigates the key factors influencing digital innovation adoption by local governments in South Korea. It focuses on demographic characteristics, electoral competition, institutional pressures, and leadership profiles as drivers for digital innovation.
research_results: The study finds that younger citizens and leaders, electoral competition, and neighboring localities adopting innovations significantly drive digital innovation. The findings suggest that demand-pull innovation and isomorphic pressures are critical to explaining these variations.
future_research: Future research should further explore the causal mechanisms linking institutional pressures and innovation adoption, as well as expand the analysis to other countries for broader generalization.
